text: All-or-nothing thinking is a cognitive distortion where you view situations in extremes — either perfect or a total failure.
Reframing a negative thought means consciously looking at it from a more balanced or realistic point of view.
Grounding techniques, like naming 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, and 1 you taste, can help bring you back to the present moment.
Catastrophizing involves imagining the worst-case scenario and believing it will happen, even without evidence. A small mistake feels like a disaster.
Mind reading is assuming you know what others are thinking, often believing they are judging or criticizing you.
Fortune telling is predicting that something bad will happen in the future as if it's already certain.
Labeling involves assigning yourself or others a fixed, negative identity — such as 'I'm a loser' or 'He's a failure.'
Mental filtering is when you focus only on the negative parts of a situation while ignoring the positive.
Emotional reasoning is believing that your feelings reflect facts — for example, 'I feel guilty, so I must have done something wrong.'
Disqualifying the positive is when you dismiss or downplay your successes or compliments, as if they don't count.
Overgeneralization is when you take one negative event and assume it will always happen — using words like 'always' or 'never.'
Magnification and minimization are distortions where you blow mistakes out of proportion or downplay your strengths and achievements.
Should statements are when you set rigid rules for yourself like 'I should always be productive,' which leads to guilt and frustration.
Personalization is when you blame yourself for things outside your control or assume things are your fault when they're not.
Unrealistic expectations can cause distress when you believe you must be perfect or meet an ideal standard to be worthy.
Comparison-based thinking is when you measure your worth by comparing yourself to others, often unfavorably.
Ask yourself: What evidence do I have for and against this thought? This can help challenge distorted thinking.
Write your negative thought in one column, then write a more balanced alternative in the next. This helps with cognitive restructuring.
Use the 'best-case / worst-case / most likely' framework to assess a fearful situation more rationally.
Box breathing — inhale for 4, hold for 4, exhale for 4, hold for 4 — can calm the nervous system during anxiety.
Journaling can help you process emotions, track thought patterns, and notice progress over time.
When feeling overwhelmed, try a quick body scan — notice sensations from your head down to your toes.
I am doing the best I can, and that is enough.
It's okay to feel this way — my emotions are valid, and they will pass.
Every small step forward is still progress.
